subject: Re: [junit] use of setUp and tearDown
msgSnippet: ... Actually, each of these methods is *not* equivalent, although they all have the same scope with respect to a given test (i.e. they affect a single test
messageBody:
On May 27, 2005, at 11:53 AM, Cedric Beust wrote:
>
> In this case, I would recommend breaking down your test class in a
> parent
> class for all the test methods that don't need this file and a
> subclass for
> all the test methods that do need this file. Then you can put the
> reparse
> of your file in setUp(), which -- as someone said earlier -- makes the
> intent obvious.
>
> Let me stress this point further.
>
> In JUnit, you have four ways to initialize / tear down your test, and
> they
> are *all* equivalent:
>
> - At the beginning and end of each test method
> - In setUp()/tearDown()
> - In the constructor
> - At the field declaration level
>
> I find that confusing as hell, so I *strongly* recommend to use
> setUp/tearDown at the exclusion of everything else. Again, the idea
> is to
> make the intent obvious.

Actually, each of these methods is *not* equivalent, although they all
have the same "scope" with respect to a given test (i.e. they affect a
single test method). Those non-intuitive differences add to the
argument that only one method should be used and the others excluded.


Notably:

setUp/tearDown: preferred, since exceptions are handled and
propagated as test results; also separates setup/cleanup from the
actual tests

within test method: makes the test method cluttered and more complex
if you properly handle cleanup within the test method

constructor/field declaration: no teardown whatsoever; whether or not
fields get GC'd depends on your test runner (the JUnit runners won't
ever release your tests, and therefore your fields remain uncollected).
note also that between this method and setup/teardown there is a big
difference between *when* the setup takes place; setup/teardown doesn't
take effect until the test is actually run, while constructor/field
declaration happens as soon as the test object is created.
